column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Cutler/OU=WHO/O=EOP@ EOP [WHO] READ:UNKNOWN CC: Sky Gallegos ( CN=Sky Gallegos/OU=WHO/O=EOP@ EOP [WHO] READ: UNKNOWN CC: Michael Cohen { CN=Michael Cohen/OU=OPD/O=EOP@ EOP [ OPD) READ:UNKNOWN
column5: It is possible that the record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, more information would be needed to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the record contains confidential advice or recommendations from Mickey Ibarra to Elena Kagan, Bruce N. Reed, Lynn G. Cutler, Sky Gallegos, or Michael Cohen, it could be considered privileged and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; Case law that supports this interpretation includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), which established that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process within an agency. Additionally, United States v. Nixon (1974) held that presidential communications can be privileged if they are confidential and relate to the president's decision-making process. ; ; However, if the record does not contain privileged advice or recommendations, it may not be protected under exemption 5. For example, if it simply contains logistical information about a White House conference, it would likely not be considered privileged and would therefore be subject to disclosure under FOIA.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; TEXT: I understand from Mike that he prepared a draft proposal for a WH Conference on education and perhaps some other meetings with specific constituencies to include mayors for you to review recently. When do you suppose it will be ready for circulation for comment by IGA and others?    I am hopeful that we may be in a position to announce at least the mayor segment when the President meets with the USCM winter meeting attendees for breakfast in the WH on January 30. Thanks.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The text appears to be a communication between two government officials discussing a draft proposal for a White House conference and potential meetings with specific constituencies. This type of communication would likely fall under the deliberative process privilege, which protects communications that are part of the decision-making process within the government. ; ; In the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The text in question appears to be just such a communication, discussing the status of a draft proposal and potential timing for its release. ; ; Therefore, it is likely that the text would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Presidential Directive on Coerced Abstinence in the Criminal Justice System January 12, 1998
column5: The Presidential Directive on Coerced Abstinence in the Criminal Justice System would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between government agencies. This is because the directive is likely to contain internal deliberations and communications between the President and his advisors, which are considered privileged and confidential.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the court held that a memorandum from the Office of Legal Counsel to the Attorney General was protected under exemption 5 because it contained legal advice and analysis that was part of the agency's decision-making process. Similarly, the Presidential Directive on Coerced Abstinence in the Criminal Justice System is likely to contain advice and analysis from the President's advisors, which would be protected under exemption 5.; ; In addition, the directive may also be protected under other FOIA exemptions, such as exemption 1 (national security) or exemption 3 (statutory exemptions). However, without more information about the content of the directive, it is difficult to determine whether these exemptions would apply.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Announcement     • Today, the President directed the Attorney General to take the necessary steps to: (1) require states to determine the level of drug use in their prisons and report annually on their progress;  (2) grant states the flexibility to use their federal prison funds for drug detection, offender testing and drug treatment; and (3) work ""1th states to enact stiffer penalties for drug trafficking into and within correctional facilities.  The President also announced that his FY 1999 budget will include nearly $200 million for a series of initiatives to promote coerced abstinence and treatment in the criminal justice system.
column5: The announcement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The announcement is a public statement made by the President and does not involve any internal agency communication. Therefore, it would not be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. There is no case law needed to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the exemption.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Towards a National Policy of Coerced Abstinence     • Last week, Columbia University's Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse (CASA) released a study confirming the need for coerced abstinence and treatment in the criminal justice system. CASA's study found that 1.4 million offenders -- or 80% of the I. 7 million criminals in prison and jails -- were either high on drugs or alcohol when arrested, stole property to buy drugs, or have a history of drug and alcohol abuse. Many other studies also confirm that the majority of individuals in the criminal justice system have similar drug histories.
column5: The above statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The statement above is not an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, but rather a study released by Columbia University's Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse. Therefore, FOIA exemption 5 would not apply. ; ; Additionally, the statement above does not contain any information that would be exempt from disclosure under any other FOIA exemption. The information provided is a summary of a study and does not contain any confidential or privileged information. Therefore, the statement would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA exemptions.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;     • Testing to Measure Progress.  Under current law and federal guidelines, states are required to submit drug testing and intervention plans for their federal prison grant funding. The President's directive calls on the Attorney General to amend the guidelines to require states to also include a baseline report of their prison drug  abuse problem, and to report every year thereafter to chart the progress they are making to reduce drug use and availability. The directive also encourages states to expand their efforts to include other offenders involved in the criminal justice system
column5: The information described in the scenario would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications and deliberative process. The directive from the President to the Attorney General to amend guidelines and require states to submit baseline reports and annual progress reports involves internal agency decision-making and policy development, which would be considered part of the deliberative process. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The baseline and progress reports required by the directive would likely reflect advisory opinions and recommendations, as well as the agency's deliberations on how to address the issue of drug abuse in prisons. ; ; Additionally, the fact that the directive encourages states to expand their efforts to include other offenders involved in the criminal justice system suggests that the agency is still in the process of developing its policy and approach to addressing drug abuse in the criminal justice system. As such, the information would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;     • Helping States Get the Job Done. Today's directive asks the Attorney General to draft and transmit to the Congress legislation that will grant states the flexibility to use their federal prison construction and substance abuse treatment funds to provide the full range of drug testing, sanctions and treatment for offenders under criminal justice supervision. With this added flexibility, states could tap into the nearly $8 billion in prison funds authorized by the 1994 Crime Law (about $2 billion of which already have been appropriated to date).
column5: The statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The statement provided is a directive from the President to the Attorney General to draft and transmit legislation to Congress. It is not an inter-agency or intra-agency communication, nor is it pre-decisional or deliberative in nature. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. There is no need to cite any case law to support this conclusion.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Doubled the Number of Federal Arrestees Tested. President Clinton directed the Attorney General to create a program to drug test federal criminal defendants. Operation Drug TEST (Testing, Effective Sanctions and Treatment) was established and funded a pilot program to immediately test defendants upon their arrest. In FY 1997, data from 24 judicial districts indicated that 56% of defendants (9,308) were tested -- a dramatic increase over the 28% (4,929) of defendants tested in the previous year. There was also a 190% increase in drug treatment for defendants over the same period.
column5: The information provided would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The information provided does not appear to be a memorandum or letter, nor does it contain any privileged or confidential information. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law: In National Labor Relations Board v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 only applies to documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. The information provided does not appear to meet these criteria and therefore would not be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Expanded Testing and  Treatment  in  Federal  Prisons. column5: It is possible that the information regarding the number of drug tests and inmates receiving treatment in federal prisons could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption is often used to protect internal deliberations and communications that are part of the decision-making process.; ; However, whether or not this information is protected would depend on the specific circumstances surrounding its creation and dissemination. If the information was part of internal deliberations or communications between agency officials, it may be protected. On the other hand, if the information was publicly available or disseminated widely, it may not be protected.; ; There does not appear to be any specific case law that directly addresses whether this type of information would be protected under exemption 5. However, there have been cases where similar types of information have been found to be protected under this exemption. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that internal agency memoranda discussing legal strategy were protected under exemption 5 because they were part of the agency's decision-making process.; ; Ultimately, whether or not this information is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; ''Zero Tolerance"lnitiative for Drugs in Prison Questions and Answers January 12, 1998
column5: The "Zero Tolerance" Initiative for Drugs in Prison Questions and Answers document would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. This exemption applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to that decision-making process.; ; In this case, the document appears to be a set of questions and answers related to a policy initiative, which would likely be considered predecisional. Additionally, the document likely contains deliberative information, such as opinions or recommendations about how to implement the policy. As such, it would likely be protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative. Another relevant case is Public Citizen v. Office of the U.S. Trade Representative, 970 F.2d 916 (D.C. Cir. 1992), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to documents that contain advisory opinions, recommendations, or deliberations that are part of the decision-making process.

column5: It is possible that the statement could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without additional context or information about the content of the directive, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the directive contains legal advice or attorney-client communications, it may be protected under exemption 5. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), the Supreme Court held that attorney-client communications between an agency and its counsel were protected under exemption 5. ; ; However, if the directive contains purely factual information or policy decisions, it would not be protected under exemption 5. In FTC v. Grolier Inc. (1984), the D.C. Circuit held that factual information was not protected under exemption 5, even if it was contained within a privileged document. ; ; Ultimately, the determination of whether the statement is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content of the directive and the context in which it was created.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;         (1) Require states to determine the level of drug use in their prisons and report annually on their progress.   Under current law and federal guidelines, states are required to submit drug testing and intervention plans for their federal prison grant funding. The President's directive calls on the Attorney General to amend the guidelines to require states to also include a baseline report of their prison drug abuse problem, and to report every year thereafter to chart the progress they are making to reduce drug use and availability.
column5: It is possible that this directive could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption is often used to protect internal deliberations and communications within the government.; ; However, it is important to note that exemption 5 only applies if the information in question is both predecisional and deliberative. In other words, it must be part of the agency's decision-making process and not simply a statement of fact or a final decision. Additionally, even if the information is predecisional and deliberative, it may still be subject to disclosure if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in keeping it confidential.; ; In the case of the President's directive, it is possible that the requirement for states to report on their progress in reducing drug use in prisons could be considered part of the decision-making process for allocating federal prison grant funding. However, it is also possible that this information could be considered factual rather than deliberative, since it simply requires states to report on the current state of drug use in their prisons and their efforts to address it.; ; Without more information about the specific content and context of the directive, it is difficult to say definitively whether it would be protected under exemption 5. However, it is worth noting that courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and have emphasized the importance of transparency and accountability in government decision-making. For example, in the case of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Department of Justice, the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals held that the government could not use exemption 5 to withhold records related to the firing of U.S. Attorneys, since the records were not predecisional or deliberative and the public interest in disclosure outweighed any government interest in confidentiality.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; President Clinton believes that our criminal justice system should reduce drug demand -­ not prolong, enhance, or tolerate it. We know that drug testing and treatment can help to break the cycle of drugs and crime.  Convicted offenders who undergo drug testing and treatment while in prisons and after release are approximately twice as likely to stay drug-free and crime-free as those offenders who do not receive drug testing and treatment. Today's directive and the resources proposed in the President's budget will help us get to zero tolerance for drugs in prison and to helps state to cut crime and recidivism linked to drug abuse.
column5: No, this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. This statement does not appear to be a communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it appear to be part of a decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the exemption.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Q.  How is this different from previous actions taken by this Administration to address this issue? Is this anything new?
column5: The statement "How is this different from previous actions taken by this Administration to address this issue? Is this anything new?" would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. However, the statement in question does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it involve any pre-decisional or deliberative process. It is simply a question seeking information about the actions taken by the Administration. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this particular statement. However, courts have consistently held that FOIA exemption 5 only applies to documents that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature, and that the exemption does not apply to purely factual information or statements that do not involve any agency decision-making process. For example, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that "the exemption does not apply to purely factual material, nor does it apply to statements of agency policy that are not predecisional in nature." Similarly, in Public Citizen Health Research Group v. FDA, 704 F.2d 1280, 1290 (D.C. Cir. 1983), the court held that "the exemption does not apply to purely factual information or to statements of agency policy that are not predecisional in nature." Therefore, the statement in question would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

Under the President's initiative, states must submit comprehensive plans of drug testing and intervention for prisoners and parolees by March 1, 1998 and implement them by September 1, 1998.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; The President has taken numerous other actions to combat the problem of drug abuse by offenders involved in the criminal justice system including: doubling the number of federal arrestees drug tested in 24 judicial districts; fighting to launch a $1 billion initiative to spread Drug Courts across the country; and expanding drug testing, intervention and treatment in Federal prisons through his budgets and the 1994 Crime Act.
column5: The statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. The statement provided does not appear to be a communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it appear to be part of a decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this statement, but courts have consistently held that exemption 5 only applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 only applies to documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative." The statement provided does not appear to meet these criteria and therefore would not be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Q.  Is the federal government tracking the problem of drug use in its own prisons? What are you doing about the drug problem in federal prisons?
column5: The question would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. The question does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency that is part of a decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. There is no case law that specifically addresses this question, as it is not a request for records, but rather a question posed to a government official.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; A       Under the leadership of Attorney General Reno, the federal Bureau of Prisons is carrying out model programs in drug testing, drug treatment, and drug detection.
column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies, including those protected by the deliberative process privilege. This privilege protects documents that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to that decision-making process.; ; In this case, if the information about the Bureau of Prisons' drug programs was contained in internal communications or documents that were part of the agency's decision-making process, it could potentially be protected under exemption 5. However, if the information was already publicly available or was not part of any deliberative process, it would not be protected.; ; There is some case law that supports the application of exemption 5 to similar types of information. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), the Supreme Court held that documents containing legal advice and recommendations from agency attorneys were protected by the deliberative process privilege. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE (1981), the Court held that documents containing recommendations and opinions related to agency decision-making were protected under exemption 5.; ; Overall, whether or not the information about the Bureau of Prisons' drug programs would be protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific circumstances of how it was created and used within the agency.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Drug Testing.   In 1997, federal inmates were subject to 127,460 drug tests. Two percent of tests were positive, as compared to the 9 percent average for state correctional systems. Prisoners testing positive for drugs arc appropriately punished and follow up tests are scheduled regularly to ensure they stay clean. Drug testing of correctional officers, and other selected employees is also an established policy in the Federal Bureau of Prisons.
column5: The information regarding drug testing of federal inmates and correctional officers would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The information provided does not fall under this category as it does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency. Additionally, the information does not fall under any other FOIA exemption. Therefore, it should be available for public disclosure.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this issue. However, in the case of Nat'l Archives & Records Admin. v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), the Supreme Court held that FOIA exemptions must be narrowly construed, and any doubts must be resolved in favor of disclosure. In this case, the information regarding drug testing does not meet the criteria for exemption 5, and therefore, should be disclosed to the public.

column5: No, the statement about drug treatment would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. The statement about drug treatment does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it involve any decision-making process. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Drug Detection. Innovative drug detection technology is being piloted at Bureau institutions.   The Office of National Drug Control Policy is working with the Bureau to provide the states with information on Lhe best ways to keep drugs out of prisons.
column5: The information regarding the innovative drug detection technology and the collaboration between the Bureau and the Office of National Drug Control Policy would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(5)).; ; The reasoning behind this exemption is that it is important for agencies to be able to communicate freely and candidly with each other in order to effectively carry out their duties. If these communications were subject to public disclosure, it could inhibit the ability of agencies to work together and share information.; ; In this case, the information about the drug detection technology and the collaboration with the Office of National Drug Control Policy would likely be considered intra-agency memorandums or letters, as they involve communication between different agencies within the federal government. Additionally, the information would likely be considered privileged because it involves sensitive law enforcement and national security matters.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "those documents, and only those documents, normally privileged in the civil discovery context." The Court also noted that the exemption is intended to protect "the deliberative process of the government" and to ensure that agencies can "give candid advice and opinions." ; ; Therefore, it is likely that the information about the drug detection technology and collaboration with the Office of National Drug Control Policy would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Q.  Is this new reporting requirement for states on their prison drug problem tantamount to an unfunded mandate on states?
column5: The question would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5 as it does not pertain to inter-agency or intra-agency communications. FOIA exemption 5 protects from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(5)). The question does not involve any such memorandums or letters, but rather pertains to a potential policy issue. Therefore, FOIA exemption 5 would not apply.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; A.      No. By  law, states  must  develop  and implement  plans  for drug testing  and  intervention as a condition of receiving  federal  prison construction  grants.  Today's action  means  that as part of those plans, states will need to add infornation on their existing prison drug use problem, and update  that  information  annually.  All 50 state correctional  systems conducted  some form  of drug testing on their  inmates  last year;   yet no comprehensive data exists on the prevalence on drug use in state prisons.  Anecdotal  reports  have shown that certain systems, such as the District of Columbia's corrections department, have had difficulty  keeping  drugs out of prisons.   The baseline information they provide  will  help us to chart states' progress to reduce drug use and availability in their prisons.
column5: No, this would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. However, the passage provided does not appear to be a memorandum or letter between agencies or within an agency. It is a statement about a federal requirement for states to develop and implement plans for drug testing and intervention as a condition of receiving federal prison construction grants. It also discusses the need for states to provide baseline information on their existing prison drug use problem and update that information annually. This information is not protected under FOIA exemption 5 because it is not an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter. There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA exemption 5 language.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; In order to provide additional resources for states to promote coerced abstinence and zero tolerance for drugs, the directive calls on the Attorney General to develop legislation to allow states to use their federal prison construction and treatment funds to carry out all of these activities.
column5: The statement may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Specifically, it may fall under the deliberative process privilege, which protects documents that are part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. ; ; In this case, the directive appears to be a policy proposal or recommendation that is still in the process of being developed. It calls on the Attorney General to develop legislation, which suggests that the idea is not yet finalized or adopted. As such, it may be considered part of the agency's deliberative process and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this reasoning is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects documents that are "predecisional" and "reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." Another relevant case is Public Citizen v. OMB (D.C. Cir. 1996), in which the court held that a memorandum containing recommendations and options for a proposed rule was protected under the deliberative process privilege because it was part of the agency's decision-making process. ; ; Overall, whether the statement is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific context and content of the directive, as well as any other relevant factors.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the record contains confidential advice or recommendations from agency officials, it may be protected under the deliberative process privilege, which shields pre-decisional and deliberative communications from disclosure in order to encourage frank and open discussion within agencies. This privilege has been recognized by the Supreme Court in United States v. Nixon and by lower courts in numerous cases.; ; Alternatively, if the record contains attorney-client communications, it may be protected under the attorney-client privilege, which shields confidential communications between an attorney and client for the purpose of obtaining legal advice. This privilege has also been recognized by courts in numerous cases.; ; Ultimately, the applicability of exemption 5 would depend on the specific content of the record and the circumstances surrounding its creation.

column5: It is possible that this email would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The email appears to be a communication between individuals within the White House Office and may contain privileged information related to internal discussions and decision-making processes. However, without additional context or information about the specific content of the email, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; One case that may support the application of exemption 5 in this context is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process of an agency. This includes communications that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, as well as those that reflect the personal opinions of agency officials. However, the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the information sought is necessary to an individual's defense or if there is a strong public interest in disclosure.

column5: The record described above would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between two high-level officials within the Executive Office of the President (EOP), discussing legal provisions related to health and human services. The fact that the creator of the record is identified as a presidential appointee and the recipient is identified as a member of the EOP further suggests that the communication is likely to be privileged.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004). In that case, the D.C. Circuit held that communications between White House staff and agency officials regarding policy matters were protected by the deliberative process privilege, which is one of the privileges covered by exemption 5. The court explained that the privilege applies to "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Id. at 1113 (quoting NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150 (1975)). The record described above appears to fall within this definition, as it reflects a communication between two officials involved in the formulation of government policy.

(1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The statement in question appears to be an intra-agency communication that would not be available to the public or other parties outside of the agency. ; ; Additionally, the case of EPA v. Mink (1973) established that exemption 5 covers "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials, which are communications that are part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. The statement in question appears to be a predecisional communication between government officials discussing their stance on a controversial issue, which would likely be considered deliberative and therefore protected under exemption 5. ; ; Overall, the statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5 due to its confidential nature and its status as a predecisional and deliberative communication between government officials.

Additionally, there is no indication that the statement was created for the purpose of inter-agency or intra-agency communication. Therefore, it is unlikely that FOIA exemption 5 would apply to this statement.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this statement. However, courts have generally interpreted FOIA exemption 5 narrowly and have required agencies to demonstrate that the information at issue falls within the scope of the exemption. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that FOIA exemption 5 applies only to documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. The statement provided does not appear to be predecisional or deliberative, and therefore would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: The record described above would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record is a summary report of a discussion of an advisory board workplan and product, created by a presidential appointee, and sent to another presidential appointee and a third individual. This type of communication is likely to be considered privileged and confidential, as it involves the internal deliberations and decision-making processes of the executive branch. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies," and that this protection extends to communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. ; ; Another relevant case is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to "documents that reflect advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "quality of agency decisions" by allowing agency officials to engage in "frank and open communication" without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Based on these cases and the nature of the record described above, it is likely that the record would be protected under exemption 5.

column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing the workplan and products of an advisory board, which could be considered pre-decisional and deliberative. This type of communication is typically protected under exemption 5 to encourage open and candid discussions within agencies. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing agency officials to freely discuss and debate issues without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The court emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the "give-and-take" of the decision-making process, and that disclosure of such documents could inhibit frank and open discussion among agency officials. ; ; Overall, based on the content and context of the memorandum, it is likely that it would be protected under exemption 5.

As such, it may contain deliberative process privilege, which protects communications that are part of the decision-making process. The fact that some topics were not included due to time constraints suggests that the document is part of an ongoing discussion and not a final decision. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process, even if they are not predecisional. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that the privilege applies to communications that are both predecisional and deliberative. ; ; Overall, the document appears to be an internal communication that is part of the Advisory Board's decision-making process, and as such, it would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Products from Advisory Board
column5: It is possible that products from an advisory board could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, this would depend on the specific circumstances of the advisory board and the nature of the products in question.; ; For example, if the advisory board was providing confidential advice to a government agency, and the products were internal memos or reports that contained sensitive information or opinions, they could potentially be protected under exemption 5. Similarly, if the products were part of a deliberative process within the agency, they could also be exempt from disclosure.; ; However, if the products were simply informational or factual in nature, and did not contain any privileged or deliberative information, they would likely not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports the application of exemption 5 to advisory board products includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the "deliberative process privilege" for agency decision-making, and United States v. Weber Aircraft Corp. (1976), which held that the privilege applies to advisory committees as well. However, the specific application of exemption 5 to advisory board products would depend on the facts of each case.

column5: Yes, the Advisory Letters to the President from Dr. John Hope Franklin on behalf of the President's Advisory Board would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption is often used to protect pre-decisional and deliberative communications within an agency.; ; In this case, the Advisory Letters to the President from Dr. John Hope Franklin on behalf of the President's Advisory Board would likely be considered intra-agency memorandums or letters, as they are communications between members of the Advisory Board and the President. Additionally, these letters would likely be considered pre-decisional and deliberative, as they provide advice to the President on matters relating to the topic of the Advisory Board meeting. As such, they would likely be protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975). In that case, the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects from disclosure "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Advisory Letters to the President from Dr. John Hope Franklin on behalf of the President's Advisory Board would likely fall within this category of protected documents.

If the feedback provided by individual board members falls under this category, then it would be protected under exemption 5.; ; However, if the feedback is not considered an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, then it would not be protected under exemption 5. For example, if the feedback is simply a personal opinion or statement made by an individual board member, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established that exemption 5 applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. Additionally, in Jordan v. U.S. Department of Justice (2010), the court held that exemption 5 applies only to documents that are part of the agency's decision-making process and that would not be available to the public under other laws.

However, if the information is purely factual and not part of the decision-making process, it would not be protected.; ; There is case law that supports the use of exemption 5 to protect pre-decisional and deliberative communications. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated" are protected under exemption 5. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE, the D.C. Circuit held that "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated" are protected under exemption 5.; ; Overall, whether the information related to leadership recruitment for on-going activities is protected under exemption 5 will depend on whether it is part of the agency's decision-making process and is pre-decisional or deliberative in nature.

Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that documents containing advice, opinions, and recommendations prepared by agency staff in the course of decision-making are protected under exemption 5. The Court emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process, rather than the final decision itself. ; ; Overall, while the language in the passage suggests that the information may be protected under exemption 5, more information would be needed to make a definitive determination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;     5. Promising Practices
column5: It is possible that "Promising Practices" could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies, including those protected by the deliberative process privilege. This privilege protects documents that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to that decision-making process.; ; If the "Promising Practices" document contains recommendations or advice related to a decision-making process within an agency, it could be considered predecisional and deliberative, and therefore protected under exemption 5. However, if the document is simply a compilation of best practices or successful strategies that have already been implemented, it may not be considered predecisional or deliberative and would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports the application of exemption 5 to predecisional and deliberative documents includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the deliberative process privilege, and Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy (1981), which clarified that the privilege applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative. However, the Supreme Court has also emphasized that the privilege is not absolute and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure, as established in United States v. Reynolds (1953). Therefore, even if a document is protected under exemption 5, it may still be subject to release if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in keeping the document confidential.

The Court also noted that the exemption covers "opinions, conclusions, and recommendations" that are part of the decision-making process.; ; In this case, the Advisory Board members are providing opinions, conclusions, and recommendations to the Initiative staff, which could be considered part of the decision-making process for the Initiative. Therefore, the statement would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;     6. Summaries of Advisory Board Meetings and Town Halls
column5: It is possible that the summaries of Advisory Board Meetings and Town Halls could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, this would depend on the specific circumstances surrounding the creation and dissemination of these summaries.; ; If the summaries were created as part of an internal agency deliberation process, and contain candid discussions or recommendations that are intended to inform agency decision-making, they may be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. This was the case in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 1975), where the Supreme Court held that pre-decisional deliberative materials were protected under exemption 5.; ; On the other hand, if the summaries were created for the purpose of informing the public about the proceedings of the Advisory Board or Town Hall, they may not be considered privileged and would not be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. This was the case in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE (617 F.2d 854, 1980), where the court held that materials created for the purpose of informing the public were not protected under exemption 5.; ; Therefore, the determination of whether the summaries of Advisory Board Meetings and Town Halls are protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific circumstances surrounding their creation and dissemination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Following each Advisory Board meeting and Town Hall, Initiative staff will produce a detailed summary of the event, including information gathered, opinions expressed, conclusions  reached, and follow-up planned.    These summaries  will be transmitted  by Dr. Franklin  to the President in a timely fashion.
column5: Yes, the above statement would be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The purpose of this exemption is to protect the decision-making process of government agencies by allowing them to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure.; ; In this case, the summaries produced by Initiative staff and transmitted to the President are clearly intra-agency memorandums or letters. The purpose of these summaries is to provide the President with information and opinions gathered during Advisory Board meetings and Town Halls, which are likely to be sensitive and candid in nature. Disclosing these summaries could have a chilling effect on the free exchange of ideas and opinions within the Initiative, which would undermine the purpose of the exemption.; ; There is case law to support this conclusion. In NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The summaries produced by Initiative staff and transmitted to the President clearly fall within this category, as they reflect the opinions and recommendations of Initiative staff and contribute to the formulation of government policies. column5: As an AI language model, I do not have personal opinions or beliefs. This exemption covers documents that are privileged, such as attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and deliberative process materials.; ; In the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), the Supreme Court established that the deliberative process privilege protects documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. This means that the documents were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice that were part of the decision-making process.; ; Based on this, it is possible that the "Additional Activities" mentioned in a document could be protected under FOIA exemption 5 if they are part of the agency's deliberative process. For example, if the document is a memorandum discussing potential policy changes and includes a section on "Additional Activities" that were considered but ultimately not included in the final policy, that section could be protected under the deliberative process privilege.; ; However, if the "Additional Activities" are purely factual in nature and not part of the decision-making process, they would not be protected under exemption 5. For example, if the document is a report on the agency's activities over the past year and includes a section on "Additional Activities" that were completed, that section would not be protected under the deliberative process privilege.; ; In summary, whether the "Additional Activities" mentioned in a document are protected under FOIA exemption 5 depends on whether they are part of the agency's deliberative process or purely factual in nature. Relevant case law includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975).

column5: The following would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This memorandum appears to be an internal communication between White House staff members, discussing policy matters and providing advice to the President. As such, it would likely fall under the deliberative process privilege, which protects communications that are part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. ; ; The Supreme Court has held that the deliberative process privilege "serves to protect the quality of agency decisions by ensuring that subordinates within an agency feel free to provide the decisionmaker with their uninhibited opinions and recommendations." NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 151 (1975). The privilege applies to predecisional and deliberative materials, but not to purely factual information. See id. at 150-51. ; ; In this case, the memorandum appears to contain advice and recommendations from White House staff members, which would likely be protected under the deliberative process privilege. There is no indication that the memorandum contains purely factual information that would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; Therefore, absent any other factors that would overcome the deliberative process privilege, the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Immigration   --  Skills of Immigrants: The attached U.S. News article discusses the issue of whether we should change our legal immigration system to strengthen  preferences for skilled and well-educated prospective  immigrants  over those that are poorly educated  and unskilled.   The current immigration system is set up to favor keeping families intact. Thus, the vast number of legal immigrants are brought to this country through family-based visas, which do  not take into account education or skill level. The article cites a Rand  study proposal  to create a point system of immigration which continues to  give  weight  to  immediate  family  reunification but  would  also give points  for education, language  skills, and work experience. The final report of the Commission on Immigration Reform also recommends a shift  in priority toward  higher skilled immigrants.    Instead creating a point system, the Commission recommends revising skill-based admissions (approximately 100,000 visas) to favor highly-skilled and educated immigrants and eliminating altogether the category of unskilled workers. Though we think that these ideas are well worth exploring, it is unlikely that Congress will want to consider an overhaul of legal immigration this year. Efforts to reduce legal immigration levels were defeated during consideration of the 1996 illegal immigration law.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the record contains confidential advice or recommendations from a presidential advisor to the President, it could be protected under the presidential communications privilege, which is a subset of exemption 5. The Supreme Court has held that this privilege applies to communications made in the course of advising the President on official matters, where the communications are intended to be confidential and the privilege is necessary to protect the quality of the advice. See United States v. Nixon, 418 U.S. 683 (1974). ; ; However, if the record is simply a routine email exchange between staff members discussing travel requests, it is less likely to be protected under exemption 5. The fact that the record was created by a presidential staff member does not automatically make it privileged. ; ; Ultimately, the determination of whether this record is exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5 would depend on the specific content and context of the communication.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; TEXT: so I'll have Andrea talk to Cathy ---------------------- Forwarded by Cynthia A. Rice/OPD/EOP on ll/24/97 10:00 AM ---------------------------
column5: It is unlikely that the text would be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The text does not appear to be either pre-decisional or deliberative, but rather a directive to have one person talk to another. Additionally, the text does not appear to be an inter-agency or intra-agency communication, as it involves individuals outside of the agency. Therefore, exemption 5 would not apply to this text.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this type of text, but courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and require a showing that the information is both pre-decisional and deliberative. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 did not protect a memorandum that was not pre-decisional or deliberative, but rather was a final agency position. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 did not protect a document that was not pre-decisional or deliberative, but rather was a factual summary of events.

column5: It is possible that the above record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without additional context or information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; Case law that may support the application of exemption 5 includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the "deliberative process privilege" for documents that are predecisional and deliberative in nature. This privilege is intended to protect the free flow of ideas and discussions within agencies, and to prevent premature disclosure of tentative or incomplete agency positions.; ; Other relevant cases include EPA v. Mink (1973), which held that exemption 5 covers documents that are "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency," and United States v. Weber Aircraft Corp. (1973), which established that the privilege applies to documents that are "predominantly advisory, consultative, deliberative, or recommendatory in character."; ; Ultimately, the applicability of exemption 5 to the above record would depend on the specific content and context of the communication, as well as any other relevant factors such as the purpose and timing of the travel requests.

The mention of a "Doggett Amendment" suggests that the record may contain legal advice or analysis, which could be considered privileged. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the attorney-client privilege and the work product doctrine are both encompassed by exemption 5. The Court noted that the purpose of the exemption is to "protect the deliberative process of the government by ensuring that persons in an advisory role would be able to express their opinions freely to agency decisionmakers without fear of publicity." However, the Court also emphasized that the exemption is not absolute and must be narrowly construed.; ; In order to determine whether the record described is protected under exemption 5, a more detailed analysis would be necessary, taking into account factors such as the nature of the information, the context in which it was created, and the potential harm that could result from disclosure.

However, case law has established that the exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process of government agencies and to encourage frank and open discussions among officials. (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated."; ; Therefore, if the record in question contains information that is part of the decision-making process or reflects advisory opinions or recommendations, it may be protected under exemption 5. column5: It is possible that the information regarding grade average and class size could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption is often used to protect internal deliberations and communications that are part of the decision-making process.; ; However, whether or not this information is protected would depend on the specific circumstances and context in which it was created and used. For example, if the grade average and class size were discussed as part of a confidential internal report or memo that was intended to inform a decision or policy, it may be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure.; ; On the other hand, if the information is already publicly available or was not created as part of an internal deliberation, it may not be protected under exemption 5.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses whether grade average and class size information is protected under exemption 5. However, there have been cases where similar types of information have been deemed exempt from disclosure under this exemption. For example, in National Wildlife Federation v. United States Forest Service, the court held that internal communications regarding the management of wildlife populations were protected under exemption 5 because they were part of the agency's decision-making process. ; ; Overall, whether or not grade average and class size information is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific circumstances and context in which it was created and used.

This privilege is intended to encourage frank and open discussion among agency officials by shielding their internal communications from public disclosure.; ; In order for the deliberative process privilege to apply, the record must meet two requirements: (1) it must be predecisional, meaning that it was created before a final decision was made; and (2) it must be deliberative, meaning that it reflects the give-and-take of the decision-making process rather than simply stating a final decision or factual information.; ; Based on the limited information provided, it is unclear whether the record meets these requirements. The Court emphasized that the privilege is necessary to protect the quality of agency decision-making and to prevent premature disclosure of tentative or incomplete decisions. However, the Court also noted that the privilege is not absolute and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure.; ; Overall, whether the record described above is protected under exemption 5 will depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case, including the content of the record and the privilege being asserted.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between high-level officials in the White House, discussing a "conservative list." Depending on the content of the communication, it is possible that it could be considered privileged and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; However, without more information about the content of the communication, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. Case law has established that the exemption applies to communications that are both predecisional and deliberative, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and involve the exchange of opinions or recommendations. See, e.g., NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975). If the communication in this record meets those criteria, it could be protected under exemption 5.; ; It is worth noting that the fact that the record was created by a presidential official does not automatically make it exempt from disclosure. While communications involving the President himself may be privileged, communications among White House staff are subject to the same analysis as communications within any other agency. See, e.g., Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 1 F.3d 1274, 1290 (D.C. Cir. 1993).

U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the court held that communications between a government agency and a presidential advisory committee were protected under exemption 5. The President also directed federal agencies to report annually on the number of classified human research projects and the number of subjects in each project. column5: No, the actions described in this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. The actions described in this statement involve the transfer of documents to the National Archives, the publication of document search guides, and the signing of an executive order to review and declassify documents. These actions do not involve privileged or confidential communications between agencies or within an agency. Therefore, they would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this statement, but courts have consistently held that exemption 5 applies only to privileged or confidential communications. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 applies only to materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, and that are "normally privileged in the civil discovery context." Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. These cases make clear that exemption 5 does not apply to the actions described in this statement, which involve the transfer and publication of documents, and the signing of an executive order.

A subcommittee of NBAC will address certain broad questions raised by ACHRE, including how to strengthen Institutional Review Boards -- the local ethics panels for Federally-sponsored research.     • In October, 1995 President Clinton directed agencies to develop plans to improve their oversight of ethics rules. The agencies have completed their review and upgraded protections, and NBAC will review agency procedures in the coming months.     • Agencies have undertaken nationwide education efforts to raise the profile of ethical considerations, and are funding research to improve our understanding of informed consent.
column5: It is possible that these actions could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption is often used to protect pre-decisional and deliberative communications within the government.; ; In this case, the actions described involve internal discussions and reviews of ethical considerations and research oversight within government agencies. These discussions may involve the exchange of memorandums or letters that could be considered pre-decisional or deliberative. Additionally, the involvement of the National Bioethics Advisory Commission suggests that these discussions may be part of a larger, ongoing process of policy development and review.; ; However, it is important to note that FOIA exemption 5 is not an absolute protection, and courts have recognized that there may be circumstances where the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in confidentiality. For example, in the case of National Wildlife Federation v. United States Forest Service, the court held that "the deliberative process privilege must give way when the material sought is essential to the fair resolution of a significant public controversy and there is no other source for the information." Therefore, if there were a compelling public interest in disclosure of these actions, it is possible that exemption 5 could be overcome.; ; Overall, while these actions may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, the specific circumstances of each communication or document would need to be evaluated on a case-by-case basis to determine whether it qualifies for protection.

However, case law has established that FOIA exemptions must be narrowly construed and any doubts must be resolved in favor of disclosure. See, e.g., United States Dep't of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136, 151 (1989).

column5: It is difficult to determine whether the mentioned record would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without additional context. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. This means that the record must be created before a decision is made and must contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to the decision-making process.; ; Without knowing the content of the record, it is impossible to determine whether it meets these criteria. However, if the record contains opinions or recommendations related to a decision that has not yet been made, it may be protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports the application of exemption 5 is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 1975). In this case, the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature, even if they are not ultimately used in the decision-making process. The Court also emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process itself, rather than the final decision.; ; Therefore, if the mentioned record contains predecisional and deliberative information related to a decision-making process, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, without additional context, it is impossible to make a definitive determination.
